Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the extent to which the 1% is paying less in taxes than everyone else. The reality is more complicated than portrayed.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to substantiate the assertion that the 1% is paying less in taxes than everyone else.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that taxing the wealthy will address both the issue of the 1% paying less in taxes and the lack of health insurance for 27 million Americans.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations or factors that contribute to the perceived difference in tax payments between the 1% and everyone else. The methodology used to calculate effective tax rates may not fully account for certain tax credits and refunds that benefit lower-income households.
